content: I have no personal blog ...no need really; if there is something important that I have to say for the world to read, then it will most likely be about Backdrop :sweat_smile: ...so I can do it on our blog. Today I wanted to rant about the upcoming Drupal 9 release, but I felt that it wasn't gonna look good if published in b.org ...I had nothing nice to say :sweat_smile:
...I am rehashing here what I posted in the "Random" Slack channel of the agency I work for:

For the past couple of weeks I've been reading articles about the upcoming release of Drupal 9 (anything that comes up after googling "Drupal 9 what's new") and everyone seems to try to get people excited about the new release (organizing release parties globally etc.) ...well, I can't help but think that it is just a hoax or a marketing gimmick ...unless you are a developer, this release simply does not add anything of substantial value.

Many of these articles try to "invent" advantages/features :sweat_smile: ...they all seem to basically say:

...there are a few advantages of upgrading to Drupal 9:
1. Easier upgrade from Drupal 8
2. Contributed modules compatibility
3. You don’t have much time!

Point 1 and 2 are the same (IMO one is basically just a side-effect of the other), because nothing has really changed. They both could be summed up in "We just did code clean-up, so nothing major to break backwards compatibility". ...and point 3, no matter how these articles choose to phrase it, it's just a joke; it just ain't a feature/advantage.

I have seen the performance tests of Symfony 3.x vs 4.x and there is indeed performance gain; same as moving from php5 to php7 - no doubt. But has anyone done performance benchmark of Drupal 8.x vs 9.x? I haven't seen any article about that. ...I am really curious to see what the savings will be in the GovCMS platform after all those ~400 sites have been upgraded to GovCMS9 :thinking: ...if there is substantial difference there, then I will be impressed.

If you are a site owner, the gist of it is that you have to pay $$$ for the mere fact that D8 will become EoL; and the irony of it is that the end product itself does not have any need for that; you'll get no "tangible" benefit in the admin UI, so nothing there for content editors and site builders (and don't anyone dare mention the new Claro theme as an argument here - it is indeed a big improvement in many aspects, such as consistency and accessibility; but it is a Drupal 8 theme; it has been developed as such throughout its dev cycle. ...it just becomes the default theme in D9 - people do not have to upgrade to D9 to get it; they can have it now with D8 if they want) ...anyway, it feels that with D9 it's just that the underlying technologies that were added as dependencies are becoming EoL (symphony basically) so the end product has no option but to follow the release cycle of these technologies :shrug:

...site builders (people that use their CMS as a lego-style site building tool and only touch code if they absolutely must) also get no benefit out of D9 the way I see it; same features as Drupal 8.9.0 really.

Bottom line is that I see Drupal 9 as a developer-focused release, with code/framework improvements. Which makes me wonder why the hell Dries is calling for a community survey? The results in 2016 clearly showed what the community wanted to focus on, and the people that drive the product did the complete opposite:
image.png
...the trigger for all that was this: https://dri.es/drupal-2020-product-survey
I feel like WordPress is MacOS, Drupal is Windows (D7 is WinXP), and Backdrop is [insert your Linux distro of choice].

I haven't looked for any marketing material on Drupal 9 but I do appreciate their change of approach from previous releases. It's a relief that it will be much easier to upgrade. That's most important to our clients as well.

From the d.org docs: "Drupal 9 will be a cleaned-up version of Drupal 8. It will be the same as the last Drupal 8 minor version with our own deprecated code removed and third-party dependencies updated."

https://www.drupal.org/docs/9

Drupal 9
Drupal 9 will be a cleaned-up version of Drupal 8. It will be the same as the last Drupal 8 minor version with our own deprecated code removed and third-party dependencies updated. Most extensions will only need a few changes. Read more about how this is done and what it means.
I think they shouldn't pretend it's anything more than something for developers. That's a good thing

I gave up on D8... not even looking at D9.

I was going to move to WP but found you guys and really appreciate your efforts on BD... Been using it for new project and plan to migrate my 150+ D7 sites across... when time permits.

I'd love to help out but time is my problem... being a busy fool an all lol.

I have built a few WP sites and using it for a 40k product webshop... but it's a nightmare, hey ho, needs must.

This is an old thread and I'm woefully behind on keeping up with the goings on in Backdrop because I've been stuck in Drupal. I'm wondering about the upgrade from Drupal 8 to 9 and I'm asking in here because it seems safer. I thought the upgrade path was easier now that Drupal learned from their mess up. Is it common for agencies to try and charge a huge cost like they did from 7 to 8? I'm looking at a site after running Upgrade Status. The report seems to say that the custom code is fine. The only thing that needs to change is updating the info.yml files to show compatibility with D9. The problems appear to be with the contrib modules that were not kept up to date. There are D9 versions available but when they haven't been upgraded it years getting to the D9 version is a problem. All of this feels fishy to me when the agency is saying that there's a lot of custom code to update. That doesn't seem like the hard part.

Theoretically, if the site/module/theme/whatever has been kept current with the latest version of Drupal, going from 8.9 to 9.0 should be no big deal. However, as you have noticed, not everyone does that, and that would be where the costs might come in.
It might also be that you could take a D9 version of a module or theme, modify the info.yml file to be inline with D8.9 and upgrade from there, though I haven't tried that, and I wouldn't take that bet. It really depends on what the module is doing and how the various Drupal version bumps affected it. YMMV.

I guess what I'm getting at is the lack of urgency to keep the contrib space updated. For example, there was a new version of Webform that is D9 compatible released yesterday but that doesn't do any good if the site is stuck on the version from a year ago. There are lots like that.
Yes, and it looks like Webform is about to lose its primary contributor, so I think that module will suffer more because of it.

The way I see it, the easy D8 to D9 and D9 to D10 upgrades seem to be a marketing trick for continuous work on sites (because that's basically a requirement in order for them to be "easy"), instead of doing it in "burst mode" when the new version of core comes out. So if you do the math, at the end of the day it's more or less the same amount of work (hence also $$) required ...just spread throughout the course of time between releases.

The one thing I think would catapult Drupal forward in this regard, is if they created an automated bot that would look at RTBC issues, look at the timestamp of when they were RTCB and then automatically commit those issues if a certain amount of time has passed say 2 months.

The biggest problem with Drupal is the fact that the community can contribute, but can't commit without jumping through a bunch of hoops to be added as a maintainer. It's great there are fixes being supplied but if they aren't being committed and released, the fixes aren't really helping anyone.

I think the biggest hurdle is figuring out how to scan the code for malicious code so it doesn't end up being automatically added by the bot. Maybe it's a matter of the bot simply flagging the RTCB for inclusion and a human reviews the code, but this has its drawbacks as well.

I guess the point is, for being a system geared towards big business and enterprise, Drupal is still a long way away from doing things that are expected by big business customers.

The way I see it, the easy D8 to D9 and D9 to D10 upgrades seem to be a marketing trick for continuous work on sites

This is much too cynical for me to agree with. I believe that the new way that Drupal manages releases is a step forward for the Drupal community and Drupal users. My gripes with Drupal 8/9 are many, but the new release cycle is not one of them.

In the Drupal world, the new path for upgrades is NOT as easy as it was marketed to be, but I do think it has and will reduce costs for most sites owners. Yes, the claims of 'ease' were overstated by an enthusiastic community with ambitious goals, but I don't think it was a marketing a trick and I think that unless you are maintaining a lot of custom code your overall cost of maintaining/upgrading your site will go down (as compared to the old release cycle). Yes, the costs of maintaining a Drupal 8 site have went up overall, but I don't see cynical marketing tricks or the release cycle as the cause of that.

@Phil Ward automated merging of changes can potentially be very dangerous @Phil Ward - code changes simply need human :eyes: ...what could help would be:

  1. larger community ...unfortunately, that in Drupal-land appears to be shrinking, and my personal interpretation of the main reason for that is the drive for a more "elite" group of developers. I also think that the idea to "get off the island" has basically not worked as they'd expected - it in fact seems to have backfired on Drupal: they were aiming to attract more "professional" developers from the larger php community, but what happened is that instead of a dev community loyal to Drupal, they got people that are excited by whatever new technology seems to be coming out every once in a while. If Drupal doesn't adopt these technologies (or adapt in ways to accomodate for them), these developers simply leave Drupal for other platforms/frameworks ...and what you get is community shrinkage over time. What they basically ended up doing is to chase the "amateur" developers that loved Drupal away ...they simply did not appreciate how hard it is to build numbers in any community :shrug: Drupal should have tried to figure out ways to retain the existing community and keep them happy, while at the same time support technologies/ways to attract new/professional "manpower" ...that could have for example been by keeping both D7 and what evolved to be D8/9/10 as two separate products, with parallel support, and allowing people to jump from the "less professional" or "legacy CMS" to the more advanced/enterprise DXP
  2. shared responsibility of project maintenance: I think that ideas like the Bug Squad and easier access to all contrib authors in Backdrop work towards that goal. Not saying that this is perfect - we definitely need more tweaking in process/permissions and how we regulate things, but the bottom line is that these methods of maintaining projects without "locking" them to only one or two maintainers, and making these few people feel as if they are "lifting the weight of the world" are good steps towards that direction.
  3. simplification of the code contribution: Drupal have only recently (this past year I believe) changed to support pull requests - it was 2020 and people still had to work with .patch files in the era of Git :rolling_eyes: ...and that could have been sorted a decade earlier perhaps (if they focused on that instead of refactoring the codebase to support composer/symfony etc.)
  4. simplification of code testing: basically https://www.drupal.org/docs/develop/git/using-git-to-contribute-to-drupal/using-live-previews-on-drupal-core-and-contrib

@StPaulTim I don't think I'm being cynical ...or maybe I am :sweat_smile: ...perhaps a realist? ...if not marketing "gimmicks", then what do you make of these:

  • "easier upgrades - but you have to keep your code up to date" ...I'm reading this as: "hidden costs over time" ... and these upgrades did not in fact end up being "easy" nor take less time/effort after all ...just work in many smaller bursts spread over time, instead of a big chunk of work (which I admin has its merits)
  • "Drupal 9 is out! ..The great news is that… there’s no breaking news at all" :shrug: :rolling_eyes: ...I agree that a new release every 6 months is a huge improvement over the old "it'll be ready when it's ready" ...I aint arguing that at all - what I am arguing is that D9 was just code cleanup, so still D8 under the hood. I'm patiently waiting for the D9 to D10 upgrade, to see what the community has to say about their real-life experiences with all these promised "easy" upgrades.

The approach Drupal is taking is the "standard" way of doing things now days. Yes, some modules won't work if the code itself hasn't been updated, however many of the modules will work just fine, they just need the info file updated to specify which versions they are compatible with, and this goes back to the problem of the maintainer not being active and no-one else having the permissions to commit the change to say it's compatible..

Drupal 9 is RC status, D8 was beta. By D10 the code base and community contribs will be stable enough that many of the issues plaguing the project and contrib will be ironed out.

Personally, I like the approach Drupal has taken. Major versions shouldn't be a big deal but rather a milestone of stability and code cleanup. Enhancements should be introduced over time, not all at once.

So, I'm in agreement with @StPaulTim that it's less of a marketing gimmick and more of the "professional" way of coding which at the end of the day, is the target market Drupal is going after.
I kind of wish Backdrop would take this approach. BD v2 scares the daylights out of me... I hated the D5 -> D6 -> D7 days.
@Phil Ward there's been talk about whether we would ever go to v2, or change the way we deprecate things / add new things
